text:
Hm…are you thinking of something similar to this but with the addition of featuring webinars too?

<https://getflywheel.com/design-and-wordpress-resources/ebooks/>

If so, to my knowledge there isn’t a WP plugin that could handle this entirely but a developer would easily be able to design and put together a page like that in a few hours which suits your brand as well…

I apologize if this isn’t the response you were looking for!

attachments.title: Design and WordPress Ebooks
attachments.text: Interested in advancing your design skills or learning how to scale an agency? We’ve written these ebooks specifically for designers and creatives.

text:
Yeah, I would just create a custom post type or more for this section, add 'ebooks' or whatever you need as a post, then add a specific page on your website that pulls in these post types.

You could then use something like the Download Monitor plugin or Restrict Content Pro to track downloads. You could also use a form asking for information, then trigger it to send when they enter in the info.

Looks like Flywheel uses a HubSpot Form where it then triggers to send the Ebook after you enter in your information.

elements.text:

text: I am struggling to think through gated content vs. blog and when you post what where. With the move toward pillar posts where longer is better and they're very comprehensive, what differentiates something like an eBook from a blog, and how do you know when to use what, where? We are moving toward using a chat tool soon which I think will help me with my conundrum because we will have a way to collect leads without gating (and we can post stuff on the blog that's more "eBook" style and use more long-form ungated content), but in the meantime, how do I do both, successfully? Let me know if this doesn't make sense!

elements.text: I am struggling to think through gated content vs. blog and when you post what where. With the move toward pillar posts where longer is better and they're very comprehensive, what differentiates something like an eBook from a blog, and how do you know when to use what, where? We are moving toward using a chat tool soon which I think will help me with my conundrum because we will have a way to collect leads without gating (and we can post stuff on the blog that's more "eBook" style and use more long-form ungated content), but in the meantime, how do I do both, successfully? Let me know if this doesn't make sense!

text: great question. i think stripping things down, the question is how you can both rank for search and offer additional value in exchange for email.

elements.text: great question. i think stripping things down, the question is how you can both rank for search and offer additional value in exchange for email.

text: There's room for some things to be fully gated, but also wanted to chime in and say that they aren't mutually exclusive! We use long-form blog posts as gated content CTAs on other posts/pages to get the best of both worlds.

elements.text: There's room for some things to be fully gated, but also wanted to chime in and say that they aren't mutually exclusive! We use long-form blog posts as gated content CTAs on other posts/pages to get the best of both worlds.

text: I think it's a matter of where that content fits in a customer's journey and for any eBook whether you are providing enough value in exchange for their email to justify gating it.

elements.text: I think it's a matter of where that content fits in a customer's journey and for any eBook whether you are providing enough value in exchange for their email to justify gating it.

text:
I like to provide the value of the long-form blog post ungated so that it can rank, then offer related content upgrate assets that are things that help the reader take action on what they've read (for instance, a checklist, rather than something long like an eBook). I've also been experimenting with having a blog guide then offering a "Download as PDF" option as the content upgrade.

One of my favourite examples of this was on Backlinko. They did a complete guide to ever Google ranking factor ungated, then the downloadable option was for a short checklist about the top 10 most important factors.

Building trust by making something of value ungated can really help motivate someone to say yes when you do present an offer. Another great option is having a newsletter subscription option so that you capture their info by offering to give them more content like what they just consumed.

elements.text:
I like to provide the value of the long-form blog post ungated so that it can rank, then offer related content upgrate assets that are things that help the reader take action on what they've read (for instance, a checklist, rather than something long like an eBook). I've also been experimenting with having a blog guide then offering a "Download as PDF" option as the content upgrade.

One of my favourite examples of this was on Backlinko. They did a complete guide to ever Google ranking factor ungated, then the downloadable option was for a short checklist about the top 10 most important factors.

Building trust by making something of value ungated can really help motivate someone to say yes when you do present an offer. Another great option is having a newsletter subscription option so that you capture their info by offering to give them more content like what they just consumed.

text:
Similar to Benyamin and Kendall, we generally offer content ungated so it can rank well and then offer the same content as a PDF download both on other related articles _and_ that same content.

It’s surprising to see how many people will download the same content as a PDF so they can keep it for later or share it around their team.

We also offer multiple callouts for a newsletter subscription in our content as users scroll down.
